headline: Starbucks' China business a 'sideshow' and 'in a tough spot'
summary: Starbucks has denied reports that it will fully sell its China business. Opening Bid host Brian Sozzi chats with Yahoo Finance anchor Julie Hyman, Ritholtz Wealth Management chief market strategist Callie Cox, and FS Investments chief market strategist Troy Gayeski to discuss why China's role in Starbucks' revenue remains limited amid slowing sales and geopolitical risks. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid here.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid here.

headline: Starbucks & China, Tesla safety review, Nvidia: Trending Tickers
summary: Starbucks (SBUX) denies a report that it's planning to sell its China business, telling Yahoo Finance it still sees "significant long-term potential" in China's market. Tesla (TSLA) is under National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) review following reports of early issues with the company's paid robotaxi rides in Austin last weekend. Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang sold 100,000 shares of company stock as part of a plan that allows Huang to offload up to 6 million shares, worth roughly $865 million. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

Tesla (TSLA) is under National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) review following reports of early issues with the company's paid robotaxi rides in Austin last weekend. Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang sold 100,000 shares of company stock as part of a plan that allows Huang to offload up to 6 million shares, worth roughly $865 million. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: How Visa and Mastercard Can Survive the Stablecoin Threat
summary: Stablecoins have a shot at being used in a lot of consumer payments.  Investors seem to be betting that stablecoins—digital tokens meant to represent a fixed amount of a fiat currency such as the U.S. dollar—could rapidly disrupt how we pay for things.  Shares of  Visa  and  Mastercard  by contrast, are on track for their worst monthly performance in a couple of years.

raw.headline: How Visa and Mastercard Can Survive the Stablecoin Threat
raw.summary: Stablecoins have a shot at being used in a lot of consumer payments.  Investors seem to be betting that stablecoins—digital tokens meant to represent a fixed amount of a fiat currency such as the U.S. dollar—could rapidly disrupt how we pay for things.  Shares of  Visa  and  Mastercard  by contrast, are on track for their worst monthly performance in a couple of years.

headline: Starbucks denies it plans full sale of China operations
summary: STORY: Starbucks has denied reports that it plans a full sale of its operations in China.Local financial magazine Caixin had made the claim, without saying where it got the information.It said Monday that the firm had held talks with more than a dozen potential buyers.Reuters sources say Starbucks did kick off a sale process for its China unit in May.It has reportedly asked potential buyers about issues including their management style and corporate culture.However, two of the sources say the coffee chain has not yet decided whether to sell a controlling or minority stake.Starbucks declined to offer any further comment on the state of the sale process.It all comes as the company loses market share in China to lower-cost local rivals.That includes brands like Luckin and Cotti.They’re winning business as China’s uncertain economic recovery pushes consumers to seek out cheaper brews.Starbucks also faces competition from ultra-fast home delivery servicesThat has seen consumers increasingly able to get very cheap coffee brought right to their door.Earlier this month, the U.S. chain responded to all the pressure with its first ever price cuts in China.

raw.headline: Starbucks denies it plans full sale of China operations
raw.summary: STORY: Starbucks has denied reports that it plans a full sale of its operations in China.Local financial magazine Caixin had made the claim, without saying where it got the information.It said Monday that the firm had held talks with more than a dozen potential buyers.Reuters sources say Starbucks did kick off a sale process for its China unit in May.It has reportedly asked potential buyers about issues including their management style and corporate culture.However, two of the sources say the coffee chain has not yet decided whether to sell a controlling or minority stake.Starbucks declined to offer any further comment on the state of the sale process.It all comes as the company loses market share in China to lower-cost local rivals.That includes brands like Luckin and Cotti.They’re winning business as China’s uncertain economic recovery pushes consumers to seek out cheaper brews.Starbucks also faces competition from ultra-fast home delivery servicesThat has seen consumers increasingly able to get very cheap coffee brought right to their door.Earlier this month, the U.S. chain responded to all the pressure with its first ever price cuts in China.

headline: Starbucks says it is not currently considering a full sale of its China operations
summary: (Reuters) -U.S. cafe chain Starbucks said it is not currently considering a full sale of its China operations, after Chinese financial magazine Caixin reported that it was, without disclosing where it obtained the information.  Starbucks has held preliminary talks with more than a dozen potential buyers, Caixin also reported on Monday, citing sources who did not specify what was for sale.  "I can confirm Starbucks is not currently considering a full sale of its China operations,” a company spokesperson said in a statement.

raw.summary: (Reuters) -U.S. cafe chain Starbucks said it is not currently considering a full sale of its China operations, after Chinese financial magazine Caixin reported that it was, without disclosing where it obtained the information.  Starbucks has held preliminary talks with more than a dozen potential buyers, Caixin also reported on Monday, citing sources who did not specify what was for sale.  "I can confirm Starbucks is not currently considering a full sale of its China operations,” a company spokesperson said in a statement.
